During his visit to Turkey, John met with Turkey's President Gul and Prime Minister Erdogan. He signed agreements putting in place a Working Holiday scheme and a Double Taxation agreement. John also visited the Anitkabir - Ataturk's Mausoleum in Ankara where he laid a wreath and signed the Book of Honour.

The Kumeu Show is the largest show in the Southern Hemisphere, and is held on 34 hectares (80acres) of land owned by the Kumeu District Agricultural & Horticultural Society, on the second weekend in March of every year. It's in John's electorate and he visits every year.

The Prime Minister provides updates on a recent SAS undertaking in Afghanistan (during which the members of the unit engaged in a firefight with insurgents) and the progress of Cabinet on issues surrounding the mining of parts of the conservation estate.  He notes that the Minister of Finance will release a major infrastructure document later this week, that the Minister of Labour will shortly release a discussion document on personal grievance procedures, that Hon Wayne Mapp will later this week release the CRI Task Force report, that Hon Gerry Brownlee will on Thursday speak at the commissioning of the Maori oil field, and that Hon Paula Bennett has today released an announcement of an increase in benefits and pensions from 01 April. He goes on to discuss his schedule for the week and takes questions from the media on topics ranging from the SAS to ministerial credit card spending, the Chile earthquake/tsunami, New Zealand's tsunami warning, and the relationship between the public and the Police.
PM expresses sympathy to Chile after quake
Press conference on resignation of Phil Heatley as a Minister in the Government.

During his visit to the Hawkes Bay Napier Art Deco festival, John, Chris Tremain and Craig Foss made a number of side trips. Here they visit the wharf (and catch up with some very brave young divers), meet with the Hawkes Bay Chamber of Commerce and talk with Napier Mayor Barbara Arnott about upgrades to McLean Park and the proposed new museum.

On arriving in the Bay area for his Art Deco festival visit, John swung by the Havelock North community centre for morning tea with the local National Party branch. After a coffee at E's Cafe, John, Craig Foss and Chris Tremain walked to the centre where they were welcomed by students from Havelock Primary.
Post-Cabinet press conference 22 February
The Art Deco festival's official opening was held just down the street from the ampitheatre at the War Memorial building. These photos are from that event.

This group of pictures was taken during a walk from the festitval's launch event and the town's ampitheatre where bands played on well into the wee hours. Lots of families, lots of costumes, lots of fun for everyone! John was hosted by Tukituki MP Craig Foss and Napier MP (and Government Whip) Chris Tremain.

On Saturday, 13 March, John, Hon Paula Bennett and Kanwaljit Singh Bakshi MP went to the Holi Festival in Auckland. From the whatsonwhen.com description of the festival: "During Holi, Holika Dahan, or the festival of colour, Hindus celebrate good harvests and the Earth's fertility by taking to the streets and smearing everyone with coloured powders and water. It's lots of fun, but watch out - no-one is exempt!"

23 February, Video Journal 22. John walks through some of the Government's proposed changes to the tax system, with particular emphasis on changes that may be made to GST. He talks about why food cannot be exempted from GST and discusses other fundamental issues of tax fairness as well as the ultimate goal of the Government in making changes to the tax structure and encourages those with concerns about rumoured changes to wait until the Budget is released in May to get a fuller picture of what is taking place - and why.

As part of his Napier visit, John stopped off to officially launch the Bikes in Schools programme at St Mary's in Hastings. He was hosted by St Mary's principal Liz Crowley, Craig Foss, MP for Tukituki, and Chris Tremain, MP for Napier. He was joined at the ribbon cutting (and on the cross country training track) by BMX world champion Sarah Walker. The programme is primarily a project underwritten by Paul and Meg McArdle of “Bike On” which provided sixty quality bikes and helmets to the school.
NZ - India relations strengthened by visit

John stopped by the Mr Apple operation ( www.mrapple.co.nz ) as part of his visit to Napier. He was welcomed by Samoan workers from the tsunami-devastated Falealili district working at Mr Apple as participants in the Recognised Seasonal Employer (RSE) scheme, met with administration staff and then went on to take a tour of the production line and talk with workers.

The children lined the driveway, forming a guard of honour for the Prime Minister and guests as they arrived at the station.

The Prime Minister discusses Cabinet's decision to sign on to the Copenhagen Accord on climate change and the attendant caveats, Waitangi Day and the basic agenda for the all-day caucus meeting coming up tomorrow at Premiere House. Q&A with the media follows the Prime Minister's announcements including a discussion of the criticisms made earlier by Dr Pita Sharples of the National Education Standards policy and further questioning on the finer points of the policy. Discussion moves on to cover the Simon Bridges bill on animal cruelty, the role of the SAS in Afghanistan and the effect of price elasticity on smoking, among other topics.

13 March. The Prime Minister participated in the celebrity cricket match on Sunday at The Basin in Wellington to raise funds for the Christchurch Earthquake Appeal. By hitting a boundary off Shane Warne, he secured a $100,000 donation from Fujitsu. Altogether, the match raised about half a million dollars for the charity. According to news sources, the match, organised by former Black Caps captain Stephen Fleming, was played in front of a 10,000 strong crowd.
With links to the websites offering more information and ways to donate securely online.
I've just launched the Christchurch Earthquake Appeal - to find out more and to donate, go to www.facebook.com/ChristchurchEarthquakeAppeal or www.christchurchearthquakeappeal.govt.nz
26 February visit to Christchurch - with search and rescue workers.
Search and rescue teams from NZ and around the world are doing such a great job. http://twitpic.com/43r7qg
Just spoke to President Obama. We really appreciate the support offered by the US, Australia and countries all over the world.
22 February visit - PM talking to locals who have come out to help

State of the Nation speech

Opening of the Northern Arena in Rodney.

Northern Arena is a state of the facility which was completed in December.  It has four swimming pools; two ten by twelve metre teaching pools specifically designed for children under 5 years of age, one seven lane twenty five metre pool specifically designed for teaching school age children to swim and one eight lane twenty five metre pool.   

The facility will have the capacity to put almost 20,000 school children through the schools programme per year and can cater for up to 8,000 children per week in their after school programme.
Flags at half-mast on Parliament's forecourt - 02 December 2010

02 November. The official launch of Hekia's campaign for the Mana Electorate. Guests included many MPs, myself, Hon Nathan Guy and Hon Tony Ryall - plus dozens of children who sang Hekia the Happy Birthday song!
PM launches Defence White Paper

The Prime Minister and Foreign Affairs Minister Murry McCully in Viet Nam for the  5th East Asia Summit. Day one - scenes from a visit to Ho Chi Minh City. Day two - scenes from Hanoi, where the summit was held. Meetings included Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard. The EAS includes the 10 ASEAN countries (Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Viet Nam) together with China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, India, Australia and New Zealand.

The Prime Minister and Foreign Affairs Minister Murry McCully in Viet Nam for the  5th East Asia Summit. Day one - scenes from a visit to Ho Chi Minh City. Day two - scenes from Hanoi, where the summit was held. Meetings included Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard. The EAS includes the 10 ASEAN countries (Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Viet Nam) together with China, Japan, the Republic of Korea, India, Australia and New Zealand.
I had a great meeting with Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott this morning.

Visit to Endace's new $5 million manufacturing plant in Christchurch. For NZPA coverage, see http://nz.biz.yahoo.com/100827/3/l7bt.html

Otago Daily Times Class Act 2010 awards, Dunedin Public Art Gallery.  More photos at the ODT website: http://www.odt.co.nz/news/galleries/gallery/entertainment/123032/class-act-awards-2010. ODT story and names/schools of recipients at http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/123076/theyre-class-act

For our Flickr photoset with higher resolution images, go to http://bit.ly/bQpM0q
At Nature's Wonders - a Reid family conservation effort on the Otago Peninsula Headland. www.natureswondersnaturally.com

Royal Albatross Centre and Fort Taiaroa, home of the only working-order Armstrong Disappearing Gun (1886).

The centre is the only mainland breeding colony for any albatross species found in the southern hemisphere. The first Taiaroa-reared albatross chick flew in 1938 and this now protected nature reserve has grown into an established colony with a population of around 140 birds.
Birthday cake with staff in the office this morning - second of the day after the first cake at TVNZ!
Thanks for all your good wishes today - I really appreciate it.
Some great questions from students at Rosehill College in Papakura today with local MP Judith Collins. Encouraging to see young people thinking about the future of NZ.
Privilege to open the new $7m science block at Otahuhu College and to see such a focus among the students on science.

Opened the new Gallagher Agribusiness Centre of Excellence at St Paul’s Collegiate School in Hamilton, an initiative designed to help meet the growing need for qualified graduates to sustain the future of our primary industries.
Addressing the Nuclear Security Summit in Washington - New Zealand takes our responsibility of ensuring nuclear and radioactive materials in our country are safeguarded very seriously.
Caught up with Netherlands PM Mark Rutte at the Nuclear Security summit in Washington.
I talked with UK Prime Minister David Cameron today about a wide range of issues, including the EU referendum.
Thinking of the people of Christchurch. The earthquake this afternoon would have been unsettling but pleased to hear there's been no reports of injuries or any major damage.
Our world-class SAS troops and the NZDF will be incredibly well served by the impressive new Battle Training Facility I opened today.
I was joined by local MPs David Bennett MP and Tim Macindoe MP to help the Institute of Directors celebrate 25 years of being in the Waikato.

With the completion of Hamilton’s Ultra-Fast Broadband build there are now 875,000 customers around New Zealand who can connect to faster internet speeds. With the national rollout 60 per cent complete, we’re helping Kiwis, schools, hospitals and businesses overcome the tyranny of distance and better connect with the world.
The New Zealand Government is pleased to nominate Helen Clark for the position of the United Nations Secretary-General.
Catching up with the Republic of Korea's President Park and Japan's PM Abe at the Nuclear Security Summit in Washington.
Tonight I attended the opening of the Nuclear Security Summit. New Zealand is committed to the goal of securing vulnerable nuclear materials worldwide.

Discussed the TPP, NZ's first free trade agreement with the US, and other economic issues with Jeff Zients - US director of the National Economic Council and assistant to President Obama for economic policy.
On a scoping mission to see if Moonbeam would like the First Dog.
Good luck to our Blackcaps and White Ferns for their T20 World Cup semi-finals. Keep doing us proud.
Saddened to hear about the death of Frank Torley, the iconic voice of Country Calendar for nearly 50 years.
Happy Easter!
Great to see Spark Digital investing in a state-of-the-art data centre in Takanini.

On 1 April Kiwi families will be better off with 18 weeks paid parental leave, an increase in the minimum wage to $15.25, $25 more a week and increased work obligations for beneficiaries with children, and around $12.50 more a week through Working for Families.
Spoke to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce about the global economy, trade and the TPP.
I've just arrived in Washington where I'll spend the next two days meeting with trade and economic leaders before attending the Nuclear Security Summit.
This week I popped out to Hutt South with locally based MP Chris Bishop. Managed to even get some sparring lessons at the Naenae Boxing Academy.
Ever wonder what a day in my life looks like when Parliament isn’t sitting? Here’s the highlights from my recent visit through the Otaki electorate.
Met Anjalee and Burma at Auckland Zoo this afternoon.
Bumped into Valerie Adams and DJ Forbes while on a tour of AUT's Millennium Institute.
An absolute pleasure this morning to have Steve and Kath from The Breeze Wellington and all the kids up at Premier House for the Great Easter Egg Hunt.

Dame Patsy Reddy is thoughtful, articulate and has a brilliant legal mind. I am sure New Zealanders will be proud to have her as our next Governor-General.
https://www.national.org.nz/news/news/media-releases/detail/2016/03/21/PM-welcomes-Dame-Patsy-Reddy-as-the-next-Governor-General
The Blackcaps and White Ferns are both two from two at the T20 World Cup in India. There's tough games coming up, but we're all 100 per cent behind you.
Local MP Matt Doocey and I had an interesting tour of Rangiora’s new volunteer fire brigade building today.
Checking out progress on the Western Belfast Bypass, which will provide better and safer links throughout greater Christchurch when complete.
Our tourism industry is growing strongly, creating new jobs and opportunities for Kiwis and showcasing our country to the world.
Met with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif this afternoon - the first visit by an Iranian Foreign Minister to New Zealand in a decade.

I was surprised and honoured last night at a dinner I was hosting for the Rotary Club of Auckland (CBD) as they presented me a Paul Harris Fellowship. Truly humbling given the incredible work Rotarians do in our communities.
My thoughts are with the officers injured in Kawerau today and with their families and colleagues.

Today is International Children’s Day. As a Government we take our responsibility seriously to try and provide for every child, regardless of their background, so they can have the best possible start in life.

We’re a Government that’s focused on the issues that matter, whether it’s growing the economy to create jobs and raise wages, through to lifting NCEA achievement rates, we’re focused on the issues that really matter to New Zealanders.
Dropped into Massey University's O Week celebrations this afternoon with local MP Jono Naylor.
Today we announced the minimum wage will be increasing to $15.25 from 1 April 2016, a 3.4% increase.
Chaired a meeting of the International Democrat Union in Colombo today.
Well done Max, great to see you doing so well!

Today I met with Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe to discuss business opportunities between New Zealand and Sri Lanka and launched two dairy development projects aimed at helping local farmers.
Moving service to remember the 185 people who lost their lives in the 2011 Canterbury earthquake.

On 22 February 2011 the Christchurch earthquake claimed the lives of 185 people. Today I joined the people of Christchurch to pause and remember those lives lost, to look back at how far the city’s rebuild has come from that day, and to also look ahead with excitement to the future and all the possibilities it holds for them. 

I’d personally like to thank the people of Christchurch who are optimistic about the future of their city. We know there’s still more to do to help Christchurch achieve its goal of becoming New Zealand’s most liveable city, and I remain committed to helping you achieve that goal.
What a way to mark your final game Brendon McCullum, fastest century in test history! What an innings!
Received a warm welcome from NSW Premier Mike Baird and his Cabinet today.

Great news today for Kiwis living in Australia with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announcing a new pathway to citizenship. This is a positive step towards recognising the significant contribution New Zealanders living in Australia make to Australian society and means more Kiwis who have made their lives there will be able to enjoy the same rights and entitlements as other Australians.
https://www.national.org.nz/news/news/media-releases/detail/2016/02/19/pm-welcomes-new-australian-citizenship-pathway
Just touched down in Sydney ahead of the annual Trans-Tasman Leaders' meeting with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull.
Here are more great reasons why we should change our flag.
An absolute privilege last night to present Richie McCaw with his New Zealander of the Year award. Congratulations!
The LGBTI community is one of the most vibrant and welcoming - it was great to catch up with many of its members and other Aucklanders at the Big Gay Out today.

New Zealand has voted to retain our current flag and I’m proud that more than 2 million New Zealanders participated in this important discussion and referendum on our national identity. Now a flag has been decided I encourage all New Zealanders to use it, embrace it and, more importantly, be proud of it.

This Easter weekend I hope you have a great break with family and friends, and remember to stay safe on our roads. I'm travelling to Washington DC for the fourth Nuclear Security Summit hosted by President Barack Obama.
Visited the innovative team at Rex Bionics who specialise in enhancing the mobility of wheelchair users.
Great to visit Rangitoto College with local MP Murray McCully this morning to meet with student leaders.
Our thoughts are with Belgians in the aftermath of the shocking attacks in Brussels overnight.
I've just announced the next Governor-General of New Zealand - Dame Patsy Reddy, who will take over from Sir Jerry Mateparae on 14 September.
Amazing atmosphere at Polyfest in Auckland this afternoon. Make sure you head along this weekend.

Opened Enterprise North Canterbury's new business hub in Kaiapoi today which will help promote economic growth in the region. It was a pleasure to meet Corbin Tait who showed me his latest school project.
Jack have I got the deal for you - two pandas for two kiwi and I will throw in a set of steak knives.
We're delivering better public services for Kiwi families.

Simon Bridges MP and I were joined by local MPs David Bennett MP and Lindsay Tisch MP to get work underway on the Hamilton section of the Waikato Expressway, the largest roading project in the region’s history.
A privilege to open Te Mahi Hou at Marsden Point Refinery, a $365m project that employed 650 contractors over three years.
Great to get the Hundertwasser Art Centre underway in Whangarei with local MP Shane Reti. Once finished it'll be a truly iconic building.
Today we introduced legislation to create the Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary, one of the largest ocean sanctuaries in the world.
Stopped in to see the staff working on the City Rail Link, a project that will double capacity on Auckland's rail network and reduce travel time for commuters.
Rousing welcome at Palmerston North Girls' High School for local MP Jono Naylor and me this afternoon.
Sad to hear of the passing of Martin Crowe today. A true legend of New Zealand sport. Our thoughts are with his family.

Our thoughts are with the people of Fiji following the devastation and loss of life caused by Cyclone Winston. We’re providing practical support on the ground and we’ll continue to assist in any way we can.
A quick wrap up of my trip to Sri Lanka last week.
More great news for our growing tourism industry.
An honour to visit Sri Lanka's Sri Dalada Maligawa - one of their most sacred temples.
Spectacular welcome in Colombo this morning ahead of my meeting with President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.

Pleased to arrive in Sri Lanka today. Thank you to Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe who came out at midnight to welcome me at the airport. The country has made huge progress since its civil war and New Zealand is helping with those efforts.
Today we reflect on the Christchurch earthquake of 22 February 2011. We remember those who we lost, we reflect on how far we’ve come since, and look forward to what the future for the city holds.
Enjoying the beautiful Sydney harbour with Malcolm Turnbull.
Fabulous evening for a ferry ride in Sydney with Malcolm Turnbull and Lucy Turnbull.

Today Malcolm Turnbull and I are meeting to discuss a wide range of issues spanning from opportunities for further trans-Tasman collaboration on trade, regional and security issues, through to continuing to discuss the situation of New Zealanders living in Australia, and the ongoing management of deportations from Australia.
Congratulations to all the winners at last night’s Halberg Awards. Great to see so many New Zealanders doing so well on the world stage and being recognised for those efforts.

Excited to turn the first sod on the International Convention Centre in Auckland, a project that will create 1,000 jobs during construction, and another 1,140 once complete, as well as provide New Zealand with a world-class facility which is expected bring an additional $90 million in tourism expenditure annually.
Looking forward to taking your calls on Newstalk ZB's Tim Fookes Morning Show from 10am.
Budget 2016 will set out the next steps in the Government’s programme to provide more opportunities for Kiwis as well as support more jobs and higher incomes.
The Margaret Mahy Family Playground in central Christchurch is impressive - it was lovely to see lots of families having fun there today.
I agree with you Bill. Stick to trimming budgets, not shearing sheep.
Congratulations to all those involved in the tourism sector for their hard work.
An honour to present the cap for Brendon McCullum's 100th test. A truly great cricketer and New Zealander. Best of luck to Brendon and the team tomorrow.
Great to visit the Ōtākaro Orchard community garden in central Christchurch this morning with Nicky Wagner
Visited the Southern Field Days at Waimumu this afternoon. Great to catch up with farmers of all ages.
Unveiled Carterton's new Charles Rooking Carter statue which commemorates the town's founder
Attended a very colourful Chinese New Year celebration at Parliament tonight to welcome the Year of the Monkey.
Today I gave my first speech in Parliament for 2016. I talked about the current state of the economy, free trade and our priorities for the year.
Gong Xi Fa Cai! Happy Chinese New Year! Wishing you luck and prosperity in the Year of the Monkey.
Great to spend Waitangi Day at the NRL Auckland Nines where the atmosphere was fantastic.
As Prime Minister, I work every day to lead a more open and confident country that backs itself on the world stage. The Trans-Pacific Partnership is an important part of that.
Great to be in Auckland today for the signing of the Trans-Pacific Partnership with New Zealand Trade Minister Todd McClay and Ministers representing the other 11 Trans-Pacific Partnership countries.
Bronagh and I were on the BBQ tonight as we welcomed the start of the Parliamentary year with the National Caucus at Premier House
Good news today for Kiwi families. Our focus on the economy is leading to more jobs, higher wages and lower unemployment.
The 2016 Chappell-Hadlee ODI series kicks off between the Black Caps and the Aussies today in Auckland and like all Kiwis I’ll be cheering them on to victory! Good luck to Brendon and the boys.
My new website is now live. Head on over and take a look, and don't forget to sign up to my email newsletter while you're there.

Great weekend of sporting results for New Zealand. Congratulations to the NZ7s team and the Black Caps, as well as Molly & Alex Sailing for winning gold at the Sailing World Cup in Miami and Jossi Wells as the first Kiwi to win gold at the Winter X Games.
An absolute pleasure to meet the lovely Jessie Robb who turns 90 today and was celebrating with her family. Happy Birthday Jessie!
Today I gave my first major speech of the year. Watch below to hear the important announcements from it.
A sneak peek of what’s in my first speech for 2016 tomorrow.
Nathan Guy and I popped along to the Karaka Yearling Sales today, an event that attracts buyers from around the world.
Was good to be back at Ratana today where I talked about the TPP and education.
Enjoyed meeting with German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin last year, a world leader who I truly admire.
The second royal visit of 2015 saw Their Royal Highnesses The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwell touring the country.
I was honoured to be able to visit our soldiers at Camp Taji in Iraq last year, where working hard to equip the Iraqi Army with the skills needed to fight ISIL.
The announcement of a deal on TPP opens the door for our businesses to export even more to some of the world’s largest economies.
It was an honour to have the opportunity to speak at the United Nations in New York last year.
In the 2014 election we promised to double the support for first home buyers, and our new HomeStart package has already doubled the rate of Kiwis receiving help to get into their first home.
From 1 July 2015 our package of free GP visits and prescriptions for children under 13 came into effect, a big help for Kiwi families.
We announced the largest ever investment in urban cycleways in New Zealand’s history, and some of the projects are already well underway.
It was great to once again visit Fieldays where the very best of our primary industries are on show.
In #Budget2015 we became the first government in 43 years to raise benefits outside of inflation adjustments, as part of a wider package to support children living in hardship.
It was hugely moving to be able to attend the commemorations at Gallipoli marking 100 years since ANZAC forces landed there.
While we didn’t get the result we wanted in the final, the BLACKCAPS still made us incredibly proud in the ICC Cricket World Cup, including a thrilling win over Australia at Eden Park.
Merry Christmas New Zealand.
We’re using assets seized from criminals to support valuable anti-drug initiatives.
Nathan Guy and I dropped into the race meeting at Ellerslie, even had a cheeky punt too.
Opened Canterbury Rugby Football Union’s new training facilities at Rugby Park.
David Carter and I got a few pointers on flying at Christchurch Helicopters.
New Zealand is taking the lead in urging Japan not to resume whaling.
Had a great time at the Special Children's Christmas Party in Auckland this afternoon, including the important task of helping Jack pick his present.
The students at Masterton’s St Matthew's Collegiate did a great job showing me around their school this morning.
Later this week I’m heading south to the Southern Field Days - Waimumu near Gore, which will be a good chance to chat to farmers and those in the rural sector

It was a pleasure to present Tim Groser with a silver tray to mark his time as an MP and Minister at the first National Caucus meeting for 2016. We wish him all the best for his new role as New Zealand’s Ambassador to the United States.
Impressive effort by the Warriors for making the finals. Congratulations to the Kiwi Ferns on their outstanding NRL Auckland Nines series win. Job well done.
Caught up with league legend Mal Meninga, and also congratulated Joseph Parker on his rise to #1 top contender with the WBO while at the NRL Auckland Nines.
I’m taking part in a live chat at Stuff.co.nz now to answer questions on the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Later today the Trans-Pacific Partnership will be signed in Auckland. This agreement is overwhelmingly positive for New Zealand – it will support more trade and investment, jobs and higher incomes.
Delighted to hear Christchurch’s amazing new Margaret Mahy Family Playground has been a hit with families, with more than 100,000 people visiting it in the first six weeks.

Thursday 7 February was a significant day for New Zealand with the signing of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) in Auckland. Watch below where I dispel the misinformation that’s been circulated about the TPP, and explain why it is such a good deal for New Zealanders.
For all those students returning or starting school this week, have a great year and make the most of the opportunities ahead of you.

For New Zealand to succeed, Auckland must succeed.

I’ve just announced several key infrastructure projects, including bringing Auckland’s City Rail Link forward by two years.
Catching up on some Cabinet papers ahead of the first Cabinet meeting of 2016.
Sign up on the link below to be one of the first to hear the announcements from my first major speech of the year next week.
Great to meet NZ’s future leaders at the PM’s Youth Programme Dinner, and hip hop star Parris Goebel.
Always great to catch up with President Barack Obama.
Probably one of the biggest highlights of 2015 for the entire country has to be the All Blacks winning back-to-back Rugby World Cups.
Our careful economic management saw New Zealand become one of the first OECD countries to get back in the black after the Global Financial Crisis.
At twice the size of New Zealand, the announcement of the Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary was a big win for marine conservation.
It’s exciting that our tourist numbers are booming as the rest of the world catches on to our little slice of paradise.
No pressure, but Paul Henry put me on the spot to name 9 national currencies in 10 seconds to win a prize for Ronald McDonald House.
Happy New Year!
In the first of two royal visits, Prince Harry toured the country, starting in Wellington.
Always great to bring a smile to deserving young Kiwis like at Easter when I helped host the Premier House Easter Egg Hunt.
I started 2015 by attending the World Economic Forum at Davos in Switzerland.
For me, Christmas is all about family and friends, and maybe eating a little too much! Have a very merry Christmas, a happy New Year, and a safe and relaxing holiday season.
Officially welcomed Judith Collins back into Cabinet today.
I was saddened to hear the passing of Jon Gadsby. A character who will be remembered for his sense of humour, and his work with David McPhail.
Great to visit parishioners at the Free Church of Tonga in Mangere this morning.
Popped into visit the team at Airways at Christchurch International Airport along with Speaker David Carter and Richie McCaw.
As 2015 draws to a close, I thought I'd share some of my personal highlights from what's been a busy year for the National-led Government.
Louise Upston MP and I got a sneak preview of the upcoming Track Cycling World Cup at the Avantidrome in Cambridge.
Bronagh and I visited the incredible street art at the East Side Gallery memorial of the Berlin Wall.
Had productive meetings at #COP21 with Irish Taoiseach Enda Kenny, Peruvian President Ollanta Humala, and Dutch Minister-president Mark Rutte.

I’ve presented United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change Executive Secretary Christiana Figueres a message from close to 40 nations calling for the removal of fossil fuel subsidies. #COP21
Overnight Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and I paid our respects to the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in France.
Met with new Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at CHOGM today.
Having a few pics with Tauranga Boys' and Girls' students.
A big thank you to Charlotte Barclay who invited me to speak at the Year 6 graduation at Victoria Avenue School last night.
Great to meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin and continue to build on the close friendship between our countries.

Pleased to announce in Berlin that the joint venture between The University of Auckland’s Bioengineering Institute and Germany’s Fraunhofer IPA will receive additional funding to help their work in developing bionic joints.
I’ve announced we’ll make an additional contribution to help research to reduce global agricultural emissions. #COP21
Arrived in Paris overnight ahead of the #COP21 climate change meeting.
Bronagh and I laid a wreath at the Pieta Military Cemetery in Valletta, Malta, which includes the graves of more than 60 men from the New Zealand Expeditionary Force in World War One.

NZ supports a new initiative announced by the Queen to protect rainforest and native forest throughout the Commonwealth. 
https://www.national.org.nz/news/news/media-releases/detail/2015/11/27/pm-welcomes-queen-s-commonwealth-canopy-initiative

Nick Smith and I have just been updated on the next stage of the Hobsonville Point home development, the Buckley B precinct, which will see 1000 new houses being developed two years ahead of schedule in response to high demand.
Our $435m HomeStart scheme is on track to help 90,000 Kiwis into their first homes over the next five years.
Regional security and economic issues were on the agenda at the 10th East Asia Summit in Kuala Lumpur today.
Arrived in Kuala Lumpur yesterday and toured the baggage handling system at KL International Airport - run by NZ company BCS.
Pleasure to open New Zealand's Chancery in Manila. Our staff here are doing a great job building our ties with the Philippines.
Great to catch up with President Barack Obama and other leaders today at the TPP Leaders' meeting to mark the successful TPP negotiations.
Pleasure to meet Chinese President Xi and Malaysian PM Najib today - we gave PM Najib a book of news reports from his father's visit to NZ in 1967.
Just touched down in Manila for the APEC Leaders' Meeting.  The focus will be on regional trade cooperation, including the TPP.
Steven Joyce and I got to try our hand at air traffic control with some of Viet Nam’s New Zealand trained staff.
Today the NZ delegation and I met with representatives of Viet Nam's Vingroup to discuss how they can expand cooperation with New Zealand businesses.
Pleasure to meet once again with Viet Nam Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung after his visit to NZ earlier this year.
Opened the new premises of Biomarine in Warkworth, a company that exports roughly 3.6 million oysters from Northland to the world.
Thankfully it was free entry for my Buddy Day buddy “Jackson Seth Danger” at the Northern Arena in Silverdale. He wasn’t so keen on joining in the morning swim class though.
Proud to support Paralympics New Zealand's fundraising dinner last night as they get ready to head to Rio de Janeiro next year. #SpiritOfGold
Enjoyed visiting the Canterbury A&P show and meeting the current – and next – generation of farmers.
Got a first-hand look at Christchurch’s new Margaret Mahy children’s playground with local MPs Gerry Brownlee and Nicky Wagner.

Good news for our tourism industry, with American Airlines partnering with Qantas to bring daily flights between Los Angeles and Auckland from June 2016. American Airlines CEO Doug Parker and Qantas CEO Alan Joyce stopped in with a gift to mark the announcement too.
I'm looking forward to travelling to Southeast Asia later this week to build on our important economic, security and political links with the region.

Seven years ago today, the 8th of November 2008, the fifth National Government was elected by New Zealanders. Since then we've overcome the Global Financial Crisis, met the challenge of the Canterbury earthquakes and supported the rebuild, became the first Government to raise benefits in 43 years, put the Kermadecs into an ocean sanctuary, got the Government's books back into order, and ended the brain drain to Australia, just to name a few achievements! It remains a privilege to be Prime Minister, and I promise that we will continue to work hard to build a brighter future for all New Zealanders.
https://www.national.org.nz/news/features/seven-years-on-national-continues-to-deliver-for-new-zealanders
Visited Southwell School in Hamilton following an invitation from their talented student Jack Austin.
Good luck to all of the 145,000 students who start sitting their NCEA exams from tomorrow. You've worked hard, now it's time to demonstrate what a great year you've had in 2015.
Exciting to launch New Zealand’s Great Walks on Google Maps, a great tourism partnership between Google, Air New Zealand, and the Department of Conservation.
My money is on Hartnell, Preferment and Trip to Paris for the Melbourne Cup. Who are you backing? Good luck to all the competitors.
Good luck to the All Blacks in a few hours time. There's a stadium of 4.6m Kiwis backing you all the way.
Visited Lloyd's, the world's specialist insurance market, to thank them for supporting NZ after the Christchurch earthquakes.
I’ve arrived in Malta for CHOGM. Many of our key trading partners are Commonwealth countries, so it’s a chance to talk trade.

I'm just back from a productive trip to Viet Nam, then to APEC in the Philippines, and the East Asia Summit in Malaysia. Trips like these over a long period of time have delivered real benefits to New Zealand and helped us build friendships across the region. And there's more to come as I fly out on Wednesday to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Malta, a climate change summit in Paris and visit German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin.
Today we celebrated 40 years of diplomatic relations with ASEAN. We will now work more closely with the region including increasing our investment there.
NZ is supporting the Philippine Red Cross to improve their ability to respond to disasters. Today I opened a warehouse for supplies which we helped build.
Today leaders of the APEC member countries are meeting to discuss issues including economic growth and shared prosperity.
Deeply saddened to hear of Jonah Lomu’s unexpected passing this morning. The thoughts of the entire country are with his family.
Yesterday I met with leaders of Viet Nam's Parliament and Communist Party who are enthusiastic about working more closely with New Zealand.
Robbed in a cook-off against Steven Joyce at the Koto cooking school - a great initiative the NZ community in Viet Nam is right behind.
Today I laid a wreath at Viet Nam’s Monument for National Heroes and at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.
Our hearts go out to the victims of today's attacks in Paris and our thoughts are with them and their families.
There’s just a few more days to apply for the Pacific Youth Awards, a unique opportunity to celebrate the achievements of young Pacific New Zealanders. Find out more at pacificyouthawards.org.nz
Visited Silverdale School this morning with local MP Mark Mitchell MP to pick up our buddies for Buddy Day.
An honour to help turn the first sod for the Christchurch Earthquake Memorial.
Had a great time at Diwali celebrations at Parliament last night.
Enjoyed having students from Mahurangi College in Warkworth pop in for a chat while they’re visiting Parliament.
Pleased to open Yashili’s new factory in Pokeno which will employ 120 people.
Opened the new head office of Waikato Milking Systems with local MPs Tim Macindoe and David Bennett.
Opened NZME's impressive new premises in Auckland
More good news for tourism and regional New Zealand, with Air New Zealand announcing they’re purchasing additional ATR72-600s to grow their regional routes.
An absolute privilege for Bronagh and I to welcome Their Royal Highnesses The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall to Wellington today.
I've just got back from an enjoyable trip to Brussels, Marrakech and London, which included taking a significant step towards a free trade agreement with the EU.
Back-to-back Rugby World Cups, what an incredible game by the All Blacks! Absolute legends!
Great to catch up with David Cameron for dinner last night. Especially enjoyed the Halloween inspired ghost meringues made by his daughter Nancy.
Popped in to the Sky TV studio here in London to record a good luck message for the All Blacks ahead of tomorrow's game.

Honoured to lay a wreath at Tyne Cot Cemetery in Belgium - the largest Commonwealth war cemetery in the world - where the sacrifice of 1,696 New Zealanders who died at the battles of Broodseinde and Passchendaele is memorialised.
Thrilled to join Jonah Lomu for dinner on his Unstoppable tour tonight in London.
Met Council of the European Union President Donald Tusk this morning in Brussels.
It was a pleasure to meet Morocco's Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane today in Rabat and to join him and some of his Cabinet colleagues for dinner.
Congratulations to Bill English and Nick Smith on 25 years in Parliament today. You’re dedicated and passionate MPs and Ministers, and it’s a privilege to work alongside you.

The Springboks are among the All Blacks’ toughest opponents, but I am backing the All Blacks to carry over their incredible form from last weekend and come out on top. Good luck to the team, looking forward to watching the game!

Due to weather cancelling my flight from New Plymouth, I road tripped to Napier last night, complete with a stop at the Speight's Ale House in Palmerston North for dinner. Not so sure about their preferred flag design though.
Was briefed by Venture Taranaki on some of the exciting things they’re doing to promote tourism in the region.
Was honoured to present Police Association Bravery Awards to Senior Constable Adrian Oldham and Constable Ben Turner.
Called Canada’s new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to offer my congratulations.
Good luck to the Silver Ferns in the Constellation Cup. I'll be there on Thursday night in Auckland to see you beat those Aussies!
Interesting chat with some of Christchurch’s future leaders from Ilam secondary schools.

Pleased to announce a significant step towards a Free Trade Agreement with the European Union in Brussels today alongside Jean-Claude Juncker.

I’ve just arrived in Brussels where I will be discussing trade. The EU is a key trade partner for NZ with two-way trade totalling more than $19.5b.
Chaired the latest meeting of the International Democrat Union in the amazing setting of Marrakech.
What a game! Springboks pushed the All Blacks hard but what an outstanding response.
Had a great time at the Hawke’s Bay A&P show with local MP Craig Foss MP. Even got a few cooking tips to impress Bronagh with from none other than MasterChef New Zealand winner Chelsea Winter.
Met the hardworking team at Fitzroy Engineering with Local MP Jonathan Young today.
Visited the stunning new Len Lye Centre in New Plymouth this morning.
Popped in to visit Simply Food in Thorndon who are celebrating 24 years in business this month.

Cheers!
We want New Zealanders to live long, happy, and healthy lives, so Jonathan Coleman and I have unveiled our plan to combat childhood obesity.
What an outstanding game by the All Blacks, can't wait for next week!
Good luck to the All Blacks as they take on FFRugby - Fédération Française de Rugby. We wish you all the best and know you’ll leave nothing out on the field.
Interesting visit around Gisborne today with Māori Party leader Te Ururoa Flavell MP and local MP Anne Tolley.
Usually I get a spade to break ground on a project, but for the next stage of the Wynyard Quarter development they let me use the digger.
Opened Griffin's NZ new state of the art manufacturing line at their factory in Wiri.
I’m proud that the National-led Government has achieved its goal of delivering a surplus this year.
Fantastic to see our tourism sector going from strength to strength.
Met Bollywood star, and New Zealand's new Tourism Ambassador to India, Sidharth Malhotra.
Officially opened Cholmondeley Children’s Centre on a glorious Christchurch day.
I’ve spent the past few days visiting our troops at Camp Taji, who are doing an amazing job in tough conditions to train Iraq’s soldiers to meet the threat posed by ISIL.
We already know it, but the rest of the world is quickly catching on to why we love our little slice of paradise.

TPP is made up of 12 countries in the Asia-Pacific region, which together account for 36 per cent of the world economy. It eliminates tariffs on 93 per cent of New Zealand's exports to the United States, Japan, Canada, Mexico and Peru.
TPP is a very positive agreement for New Zealand, improving access to international markets and supporting Kiwi exporters to grow and create new jobs.
TPP will save $259 million a year in tariffs, and will benefit our economy by at least $2.7 billion a year by 2030.
New Zealand’s biggest trade deal, the TPP, has been agreed. It will support more jobs, higher incomes and a better standard of living for New Zealanders.
Met with other Pacific leaders and UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon at the UN today to discuss Pacific regional issues.
Visiting the UN Security Council chamber. New Zealand is working hard to repay the faith UN members showed when they elected us to the council.
Fantastic to experience one of the great sports rivalries - watching the New York Yankees play the Boston Red Sox.
Visiting Air New Zealand's Pleased to Seat You tour in New York City. Great to see more direct links between NZ and the USA making it easier for even more people to come visit us.
Caught up with leaders from Sri Lanka, Malta, the Netherlands and the Pacific today at the UN General Assembly.
Quick catch-up with President Barack Obama after his speech to the UN General Assembly.

The Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary will be one of the world’s largest and most significant fully-protected areas, preserving important habitats for seabirds, whales and dolphins, endangered marine turtles and thousands of species of fish and other marine life. It will cover 15 per cent of New Zealand’s Exclusive Economic Zone, an area twice the size of our landmass, and 50 times the size of our largest national park in Fiordland.
Great to be in New York for the 70th UN General Assembly. Our focus this week will be on issues including our Security Council priorities and the TPP negotiations.
Great afternoon tea to celebrate the achievements of our Special Olympics team.
Sharing a nice surprise from Timaru Airport yesterday - Roncalli College student Caitlin Bradley singing about the flag debate.
Interesting visit to Holcim in Timaru, including the very impressive inflatable dome used to store concrete.
Caught the tram into Christchurch today with Prince Harry. Great to see so many people coming out to meet him.
We want New Zealanders to live long, happy, and healthy lives, so Jonathan Coleman and I have unveiled our plan to combat childhood obesity.
I had a great afternoon at the Auckland Diwali Festival. Happy Diwali!
A pleasure to welcome Australian PM Malcolm Turnbull to New Zealand this morning.
The TPP gives New Zealand exporters better access to 40 per cent of the global economy. It's great for jobs, great for the economy, and a great deal for New Zealand.
Tune in from 11.15am to my first ever Google Hangout with New Zealand secondary schools.
Thanks to the success of the Government's economic plan to create sustainable growth, New Zealand is one of the first OECD countries to return to surplus following the Global Financial Crisis.
I've really enjoyed the past two weeks overseas, where I announced a new marine sanctuary almost the size of France, addressed the U.N., and visited our troops in Iraq.
To give an idea of the scale of the TPP, over a quarter of all household consumption in the world happens in the United States, which is just one of the TPP partners.
Met the good folk at Mitre 10 on Ferry Rd in Christchurch today where the flag debate is flying high.
Great to be able to welcome these families into their new homes built by Habitat for Humanity.

TPP is our first free trade relationship with the United States and Japan – the world’s largest and third largest economies. New Zealand will now have free trade agreements with our top five trading partners.
New Zealand exported $28 billion in goods and services to our new TPP partners in 2014, which is around 40 per cent of New Zealand’s overall exports.
800 million potential customers for New Zealand goods and services.
TPP will allow New Zealand exporters to sell more goods and services to the world.
It may not be the big screen but whatever it takes to catch the All Blacks when you're travelling right?
Speaking at the UN General Assembly calling on the UN Security Council to show greater leadership on some of the serious issues the world faces today.
Catching up with New York-based NZ businesses, their customers and a few ex-pats too – all doing great things here.
Pleasure to catch up with Helen Clark at the UNDP this morning, and to deliver her some fine New Zealand wine.
Today I attended President Barack Obama's summit on countering ISIL and violent extremism. New Zealand is playing its role in this important coalition.
Fiji Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama and I met formally for the first time today.

Proud to announce a 620,000 km2 Kermadec Ocean Sanctuary at the United Nations this morning. This sanctuary will be twice the size of New Zealand. The Kermadecs is a world-class, unspoiled marine environment and New Zealand will now protect it for future generations.
With Foreign Minister Murray McCully at the 70th UN General Assembly.
I’ve just announced the creation of a 620,000 km2 Ocean Sanctuary in the Kermadec region, one of the most pristine and unique environments on Earth.
Impressed with the students at Rangitikei College who are going through NCEA assessments at the moment. They even let me try out their digger!
Fascinating visit to rural veterinarians Southern Rangitikei Vets.
Stopped off for coffee and a snack. Tough choice though, sausage roll or pie?
Since the National-led Government was re-elected, we’ve been working hard to build a stronger and more prosperous New Zealand.
A year ago today the National-led Government was successfully re-elected. Our commitment to delivering a more prosperous, vibrant, and confident New Zealand remains as strong as ever.
Today I officially opened the NZ Classic Motorcycle Museum in Nelson — a great drawcard for the city.
Great to witness the signing of a partnership between China Southern Airlines and Christchurch Airport which will see even more tourists visiting the South Island.
Great to speak to the Porirua Chamber of Commerce this morning with local MP Hekia Parata.
I've just phoned new Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to offer him my congratulations.
Congratulations Lydia Ko on your win at the Evian Championship and becoming the youngest ever major winner in women's golf. Amazing stuff!
Quick photo before the Leaders' Retreat at the Pacific Islands Forum kicks off.
Today in Parliament Bill English led the acknowledgement of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II becoming the longest reigning monarch of Britain.
Da jia hao 大家好. This week marks the first Chinese Language Week, and with New Zealand having a rich history of Chinese immigration, and strong links to China, I encourage everyone to get involved.
New Zealand will be welcoming 750 Syrian refugees over the next two and a half years in response to the ongoing conflict in Syria.
Visited South Island Seed Dressing & Storage with local MP Jo Goodhew. Impressive facility that’s benefitting from increased irrigation in the region.

Good luck to the All Blacks who kick off their Rugby World Cup campaign against Argentina tomorrow morning. There'll be plenty of early morning starts over here as the entire country cheers you on. Go the mighty All Blacks, bring home the cup!

I’m in the North Shore with Minister for Senior Citizens Maggie Barry MP who’s just launched the new Super Seniors website: http://superseniors.msd.govt.nz A one-stop gateway for information on everything from SuperGold cards to community events.
Visited Pic Picot and the team at Pic's Really Good Peanut Butter where they put me straight to work filling peanut butter jars.
Last week I was at the Pacific Forum where I announced that over the next three years New Zealand will provide $1b in economic development aid for the region.
On Friday, I officially re-opened the NZTE office in Port Moresby and announced Peter Hobbs as the new Trade Commissioner to Papua New Guinea.
Catching up over a beer with Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott and Papua New Guinean Prime Minister Peter O'Neill after another constructive Pacific Islands Forum.
Joint presser with PMs Abbott and O'Neill, and President Tong to wrap up Leaders' Retreat in PNG.
Caught up with Solomon Islands PM Manasseh Sogavare at the Pacific Islands Forum in PNG.
Arrived in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea for the official opening of the 46th Pacific Island Forum.
Had a good visit to Waihi College on Wednesday. Didn’t expect to get challenged to an arm wrestle though.
Five years on from the 7.1 earthquake we remain committed to making Canterbury even better than it was.
Pleasure to open the Breakfree Hotel in Christchurch. Good to see tourism numbers supporting growth in the industry.
Great to meet some of the locals at the Whangamata Memorial Hall.
Impressive senior students at Epsom Girls’ Grammar School – visiting with local list MP Paul Goldsmith.

The final four flag designs for the referendum have been announced. What do you think of them?

Congratulations Scott Dixon on winning your fourth IndyCar Series title today, a great achievement by a Kiwi excelling on the world stage.
Got to visit one of Oamaru’s craft beer breweries yesterday - Scotts Brewing Co. Managed to get a cheeky free sample too.
Opened Oamaru’s modern new business park with local MP Jacqui Dean MP.
Enjoyed a warm welcome from the hard working team at Gillies Foundry and Engineering.
A pleasure to launch the redevelopment of 47 The Esplanade in Petone with Chris Bishop. A great project for the Hutt.
Our HomeStart package has already helped more than 2,000 Kiwis into their first homes.

Honoured to welcome Cook Islands Prime Minister Henry Puna and to lay a wreath together to commemorate the involvement of New Zealand and Cook Islands soldiers in World War One at the Auckland War Memorial.
Celebrated last night with the recipients of the Prime Minister's Business Scholarships, helping develop the next generation of New Zealand innovators and leaders.
Pleased to catch up with NSW Premier Mike Baird today. Didn't give him too much of a hard time about the rugby result.
Celebrating the arrival of the 57th and final electric train in Auckland - marking the culmination of the Government's $1.6 billion decade-long investment in three metro rail projects.
Good luck Silver Ferns for your semi-final against England today! We’re all cheering for you.
Opening Steel & Tube's new premises in Auckland - New Zealand's leading distributor and processor of steel products.
Thank you all so much for signing my birthday card, it's humbling to receive so many fantastic birthday greetings.
I was privileged to lay a wreath and remember the battle of Chunuk Bair, as well as meeting serving defence force personnel and their families, in Singapore today.
Had the pleasure of opening Paula Bennett's new electorate office this afternoon. It seems Paula thinks flattery will get you everywhere though...
Helped raise funds for the Well Foundation and Rotary Youth Driver Awareness over lunch today. Great to be able to support these worthy causes.
Congratulations to our Special Olympics team for their 32 medal haul  in Los Angeles. Outstanding effort!
Attended a prayer and cultural service ahead of the Constitution Day celebrations later on today in Rarotonga.
It was a pleasure to visit Pukekohe High School this morning and to meet some outstanding young students.
Along with Simon Bridges MP, Anne Tolley and Todd Muller, today I opened the $455m Tauranga Eastern Link, part of the Government's Roads of National Significance programme.
It's important to remember that, despite challenging news globally, the New Zealand economy is resilient and performing well.
Did you do anything for Random Act of Kindness Day? I gave Edward Rowe my silver fern lapel pin.
I'll be doing a live chat on Stuff.co.nz from 3:45pm. Looking forward to taking your questions about the flag designs.
Really impressed with the new $5 and $10 bank note designs, lots of new security features to prevent counterfeiting in them too.
A great privilege to attend tonight's All Blacks announcement at Parliament. I have no doubt they'll do NZ proud.
Good luck to the New Zealand Rowing Team at the World Rowing Champs starting on Sunday. Go well and compete hard.
Local MP Jacqui Dean MP and I delivering some happy news to the people of Oamaru - close to $1m in extra funding to complete the Alps 2 Ocean cycle trail.
Stopped off on the way out of Dunedin to pick up some daffodils for Daffodil Day.
Great to be in Dunedin tonight to celebrate Otago's top young achievers at the Class Act Awards.
It's great news for the New Zealand economy that tourist numbers are reaching record levels, and those tourists are staying longer and spending more.
More tourists are coming to New Zealand than ever before and they’re spending more and staying longer, creating jobs and opportunities for New Zealanders.
Visited Campbells Bay School to tour their brand new classrooms. Thanks for the fantastic welcome.
Met Bodhi the puppy this afternoon. Very wriggly, but very cute. No one tell Moonbeam.
Opened Stage 1 of the Central Plains Water irrigation scheme in Canterbury which has the potential to create more than $1b in new economic activity.
Great to Skype with Year 9 students at Hamilton Girls' High School over lunch, even though we had to improvise a stand for the iPad.
Come on Silver Ferns! All the best for today’s Netball World Cup final against the Diamonds. You’ve got the whole country backing you.

It was a great pleasure to speak today at the celebrations commemorating 50 years of Cook Island self governance in free association with New Zealand.

Today I arrived in the Cook Islands to celebrate a significant milestone in New Zealand’s special relationship with the Cook Islands. Tomorrow we will celebrate 50 years of Cook Islands self-governance in free association with New Zealand. When that arrangement was agreed to in 1965 it was unprecedented, and today our relationship is stronger than ever. To mark the occasion, I also announced that New Zealand will contribute up to $11.7m to the rebuild of the national secondary school, Tereora College.

- #TeamKey

Another popular moment was the Monday after Election Day, where John Key and Bill English welcomed National’s impressive class of 2014 to Parliament. Fourteen outstanding candidates joined National’s ranks.
- #TeamKey
Happy New Year!

Last month I announced a review of security settings around foreign fighters and today I have outlined the urgent changes needed to address the evolving threat environment. ntnl.org.nz/1x5hQT7

When we gather together to commemorate the ANZACs we mark no single military battle. We remember the sacrifice of our service men and women in many conflicts, and campaigns, far from home.

Last night the Countering Terrorist Fighters Legislation Bill was passed into law in Parliament. I want to thank the Labour Party and our colleagues in UnitedFuture and ACT for supporting this important legislation.

The Government has an obligation to ensure New Zealanders are safe at home and abroad. This legislation provides us with measures that will add to the safety and security of New Zealand. It will better enable us to deal with the rapidly evolving threat posed by foreign terrorist fighters and growing international terrorism in the short-term.

Today I outlined National’s position on accommodating support parties in electorate contests at this year’s General Election.
 
We will encourage National party supporters to give their electorate vote to the ACT candidate in Epsom and the United Future candidate in Ohariu. In East Coast Bays, Murray McCully will be competing for the electorate vote.
 
Whatever happens in those seats, we will be focused on maximising the party vote for National across the country in all seats. It is only through delivering the strongest possible party vote that National voters will return National to Government.

Prime Minister John Key will lead a small group of New Zealanders to pay respects to Nelson Mandela at his official memorial service in South Africa.

“Nelson Mandela was a global icon for freedom who united South Africans following apartheid,” says Mr Key.

“Madiba’s achievements demonstrate what can be attained through forgiveness and reconciliation. His vision for South Africa was one of freedom and equality. It remains an inspiration to the world.”

Mr Key will be accompanied by the Minister of Maori Affairs, Hon Dr Pita Sharples; Leader of the Opposition, Hon David Cunliffe, former Prime Minister of New Zealand, the Rt Hon Jim Bolger; and former Foreign Minister and Secretary‑General of the Commonwealth, the Rt Hon Sir Don McKinnon.

Continue reading: http://johnkey.co.nz/archives/1773-PM-to-lead-small-delegation-to-South-Africa.html

Philippines visit postponed - further support offered
http://johnkey.co.nz//archives/1762-Philippines-visit-postponed-further-support-offered.html

Prime Minister John Key announced today that New Zealand is sending an RNZAF Hercules to contribute to relief efforts in the wake of Typhoon Haiyan.

The Prime Minister also announced the postponement of his visit to the Philippines.

“A visit next week would place undue pressure on the Philippines Government at a critical time of the relief and recovery phase.

“New Zealand knows from recent experience in Christchurch how demanding responding to a large-scale disaster is and we don’t wish to distract from these efforts.

“An RNZAF C-130 Hercules carrying emergency supplies will depart New Zealand tomorrow for the Philippines. The aircraft will remain in the area for at least 4 – 5 days to provide transport support to relief efforts as required,” says Mr Key.

Continue reading: http://johnkey.co.nz//archives/1762-Philippines-visit-postponed-further-support-offered.html

PM to visit UK, France and attend UNGA
http://johnkey.co.nz//archives/1719-PM-to-visit-UK,-France-and-attend-UNGA.html

Prime Minister John Key will visit the United Kingdom, France and the United Nations in New York from 17-29 September.

Mr Key’s visit to Britain will include bilateral meetings with UK Prime Minister David Cameron, Foreign Secretary William Hague and the Leader of the Opposition, Ed Milliband.

In France, Mr Key will meet President Francois Hollande, Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault, and Economy and Finance Minister Pierre Moscovici. This will be Mr Key’s first visit to France since Mr Hollande became President last year.

“Europe remains vital to New Zealand’s future prosperity and security,” says Mr Key.

Prime Minister John Key will lead the New Zealand delegation, which includes Foreign Affairs Minister Murray McCully, to the 44th Pacific Islands Forum in the Republic of Marshall Islands next week.

The Marshall Islands has highlighted climate change as a major theme for the leaders of the Forum’s 16 member states to discuss at this year’s meeting in the capital, Majuro.

Media release: Prime Minister congratulates Tony Abbott
http://johnkey.co.nz/archives/1718-Prime-Minister-congratulates-Tony-Abbott.html

Prime Minister John Key has today congratulated Tony Abbott on his victory in the Australian election.

“I passed on my congratulations to Tony Abbott last night, and will relay my congratulations in person when I speak to him today,” says Mr Key.

“I look forward to working with Australia’s new Prime Minister to build on the close unique relationship that exists between New Zealand and Australia.

“We will have several opportunities to meet over the next few months to discuss how our two countries can continue to work together.

“Australia is our most important relationship. Our common interests span trade, economic, defence and security matters and we cooperate closely in our region and on the international stage.

“In the term of this new Australian Government, New Zealand and Australia will commemorate the centenary of the First World War and the Gallipoli landings, where the ANZAC spirit was forged. We will also jointly host the Cricket World Cup in 2015.

“These events remind us of the many bonds between our two countries, whether historical, cultural or on the sporting field, and of the importance of preserving and extending our relationship,” says Mr Key.

Prime Minister John Key today announced a $5 million initiative to help five low-lying Pacific countries vulnerable to water shortages to better manage their fresh water resources.

“For a number of Pacific countries, access to safe, clean drinking water is not guaranteed. Ensuring communities and businesses can access clean drinking water will go a long way to improving people’s health and livelihoods,” Mr Key says.

“As part of a practical solution, we have entered into a new five-year partnership with the Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC) to improve water security in Tuvalu, Tokelau, Kiribati, the Cook Islands and the Republic of the Marshall Islands.

PM: Third reading speech on GCSB legislation
http://johnkey.co.nz/archives/1707-Third-reading-speech-on-GCSB-legislation.html

Mr Speaker, this is an essential Bill which has attracted a lot of debate, much of it alarmist.

It’s one of the strengths of our country that people who oppose legislation have an opportunity to say so.

That’s their right, whether or not they understand what that legislation will actually do.   

Some people are fundamentally opposed to the work of our intelligence agencies.

Those critics oppose the agencies almost on principle. 

As Prime Minister, I am not one of those people.

That’s because I have access to evidence which shows that without the GCSB and NZSIS, our national security would be vulnerable.

There are threats our Government needs to protect New Zealanders from. Those threats are real and ever-present and we under-estimate them at our peril.

New Zealanders are entitled to expect that their security is something that the Government takes seriously. And we do. We take it very seriously.

But we can’t say we take it seriously, and then not make the tools available to allow our security services to do their job.

That is the opposite of taking security seriously.

And that is something I will never do.

Speech to New Zealand National Service, United Nations Memorial Cemetery, Busan, South Korea
http://johnkey.co.nz/archives/1693-Speech-to-New-Zealand-National-Service,-United-Nations-Memorial-Cemetery,-Busan,-South-Korea.html

! would like to begin by specially acknowledging the presence of our party of New Zealand Korean War veterans who have journeyed to Korea to pay their respects to their fallen comrades and mark the 60th anniversary of the end of fighting in the Korean War. Sixty years ago yesterday the guns fell silent across the Korean peninsula.

The armistice that ended hostilities in the devastating war that had raged across this country for more than three years had come into effect.

This terrible conflict, that claimed three million lives, began on 25 June 1950 when North Korea launched an all-out invasion of its southern neighbour. The United Nations responded promptly to this act of blatant aggression by asking its members to help defend the Republic of Korea. Sixteen nations answered this call by sending combat troops and others provided non-combatant support.

Within days New Zealand offered the services of two Royal New Zealand Navy frigates. In July New Zealand decided to commit a ground force based on an artillery regiment to serve as part of the United Nations Command. New Zealand's contribution was small, but was a significant one for our country. In total about 6000 Royal New Zealand Navy and New Zealand Army personnel served in Korea between 1950 and 1957 of whom 45 lost their lives.

We are here to remember the heroism and the sacrifices of Korean and allied troops from 21 nations large and small, including my country New Zealand, which answered the call of the Korean government and the United Nations.

We remember with gratitude those who gave their lives to defend freedom, as well as the many thousands who were wounded.

We also thank the veterans of the conflict, many of whom are here today.
